awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Markerless biomechanical evaluation of musculoskeletal disorders to improve rehabilitation outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a technology to evaluate musculoskeletal (MSK) disorders to improve rehabilitation outcomes. Musculoskeletal disorders lower the quality of life for millions of affected individuals, result in increased national healthcare costs, and are a leading cause of lost workdays in the United States.  The proposed technology may help patients with musculoskeletal disorders better understand the biomechanical root cause of their problem, inform their rehabilitation plan, and improve their recovery outcome.  In addition, the proposed technology may improve the process for patient evaluation, patient outcomes, and reporting requirements for insurance reimbursement of healthcare providers.  

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a markerless biomechanical evaluation technology. The proposed technology is designed to automate the collection, analysis, and reporting of biomechanical data for patients with musculoskeletal disorders.  The technology uses a markerless motion capture camera device (hardware) along with corresponding analysis and reporting software to provide actionable biomechanical evaluations to patients with lower back pain, lower limb musculoskeletal disorders, and general musculoskeletal disorders to improve rehabilitation outcomes.  Patients are recorded and the video is processed using computer vision algorithms that generate virtual biomarkers identifying the patient’s body position and joint angles.  This information may be used for biomechanical analysis to identify movement deficiencies and may provide insight into finding the root cause of the patient’s pain and create the foundation for actionable reporting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio

por.por_cntn:
Our team developed a markerless motion capture technology specialized in evaluating the physical therapy process outcomes. Such technology can benefit practitioners, such as sports medicine professionals, physical therapists, and chiropractors, as well as patients. The technology has the potential to increase the efficiency of practitioners by providing a way to automatically collect musculoskeletal dynamics data without the physical presence of the practitioner. This also supports the reporting phase, thus freeing time for the evaluation and treatment phases. From a patient perspective, the data collected by our technology provides an objective numeric representation of their musculoskeletal dynamics. A numeric metric can improve the understanding of the patient which, in turn, can trigger patient engagement in physical therapy activities. 

The major goal of this project was to perform a customer and industry discovery process to assess the business potential of this technology applied to post-surgery recovery and physical therapy treatments. The major activities planned for this project included interviews with physical therapists and potential customers, and participation in industry conferences to evaluate the competition and the potential market. After more than 200 interviews and three conferences, we created a deeper understanding of the markets need from both patient and customer perspectives. Practitioners, in particular physical therapists, lament patient’s disengagement at the point that rarely their patients terminate the prescribed cycle of therapy. Patients, on the other side, explain that the lack of objective feedback is the main factor in dropping the cycle of treatment. In addition, practitioners need a more effective way to prepare the reports for both patients and insurances. Since the average time for reporting is about 30 minutes for each patient, we discovered that our technology could save at least 75% of it, thus increasing the profitability of the practice. 

An additional outcome, but not less important, is the set of business skills and domain-specific market knowledge developed by the members of our team. In particular, we applied the scientific method of testing hypotheses through experiments to create a documented understanding of the market. Such method and skillsets related to it constitute an important step in the professional development of each team member.

 


Last Modified: 07/18/2023
Modified by: Gianluca Zanella
